Transferable	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Transferable interface represents an object that can be transfered between different execution contexts, like the main thread and Web workers.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Transferable
TransitionEvent	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Transition Event interface represents events providing information related to transitions.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TransitionEvent
TransitionEvent.animationName	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TransitionEvent.transitionName read-only property is a DOMString containing the name of the CSS property associated with the transition.</p><pre><code>name = TransitionEvent.transitionName</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TransitionEvent/animationName
TransitionEvent.elapsedTime	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TransitionEvent.elapsedTime read-only property is a float giving the amount of time the animation has been running, in seconds, when this event fired. This value is not affected by the transition-delay property.</p><pre><code>name = TransitionEvent.elapsedTime</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TransitionEvent/elapsedTime
TransitionEvent.initTransitionEvent()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TransitionEvent.initTransitionEvent() method Initializes a transition event created using the deprecated Document.createEvent("TransitionEvent") method.</p><pre><code>transitionEvent.initTransitionEvent(typeArg, canBubbleArg, cancelableArg, transitionNameArg, elapsedTimeArg);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TransitionEvent/initTransitionEvent
TransitionEvent.pseudoElement	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TransitionEvent.pseudoElement read-only property is a DOMString, starting with '::', containing the name of the pseudo-element the animation runs on. If the transition doesn't run on a pseudo-element but on the element, an empty string: ''.</p><pre><code>name = TransitionEvent.pseudoElement</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TransitionEvent/pseudoElement
TransitionEvent()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TransitionEvent() constructor returns a newly created TransitionEvent, representing an event in relation with an transition.</p><pre><code>transitionEvent = new TransitionEvent(type, {animationName: aPropertyName, \n                                             elapsedTime  : aFloat, \n                                             pseudoElement: aPseudoElementName});\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TransitionEvent/TransitionEvent
TreeWalker	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker object represents the nodes of a document subtree and a position within them.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker
TreeWalker.currentNode	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.currentNode property represents the Node on which the TreeWalker is currently pointing at.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.currentNode;\ntreeWalker.currentNode = node;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/currentNode
TreeWalker.filter	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.filter read-only property returns a NodeFilter that is the filtering object associated with the TreeWalker.</p><pre><code>nodeFilter = treeWalker.filter;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/filter
TreeWalker.firstChild()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.firstChild() method moves the current Node to the first visible child of the current node, and returns the found child. It also moves the current node to this child. If no such child exists, returns null and the current node is not changed.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.firstChild;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/firstChild
TreeWalker.lastChild()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.lastChild() method moves the current Node to the last visible child of the current node, and returns the found child. It also moves the current node to this child. If no such child exists, returns null and the current node is not changed.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.lastChild();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/lastChild
TreeWalker.nextNode()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.nextNode() method moves the current Node to the next visible node in the document order, and returns the found node. It also moves the current node to this one. If no such node exists, returns null and the current node is not changed.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.nextNode();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/nextNode
TreeWalker.nextSibling()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.nextSibling() method moves the current Node to its next sibling, if any, and returns the found sibling. I there is no such node, return null and the current node is not changed.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.nextSibling();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/nextSibling
TreeWalker.parentNode()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.parentNode() method moves the current Node to the first visible ancestor node in the document order, and returns the found node. If no such node exists, or if it is above the TreeWalker 's root node, returns null and the current node is not changed.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.parentNode();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/parentNode
TreeWalker.previousNode()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.previousNode() method moves the current Node to the previous visible node in the document order, and returns the found node. It also moves the current node to this one. If no such node exists,or if it is before that the root node defined at the object construction, returns null and the current node is not changed.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.previousNode();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/previousNode
TreeWalker.previousSibling()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.previousSibling() method moves the current Node to its previous sibling, if any, and returns the found sibling. I there is no such node, return null and the current node is not changed.</p><pre><code>node = treeWalker.previousSibling();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/previousSibling
TreeWalker.root	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.root read-only property returns the node that is the root of what the TreeWalker traverses.</p><pre><code>root = TreeWalker.root;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/root
TreeWalker.whatToShow	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The TreeWalker.whatToShow read-only property returns an unsigned long being a bitmask made of constants describing the types of Node that must to be presented. Non-matching nodes are skipped, but their children may be included, if relevant. The possible values are:</p><pre><code>nodeTypes = treeWalker.whatToShow;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TreeWalker/whatToShow
UDP Socket API	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>//TODO: docs are missing, see https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=745283</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UDP_Socket_API
UIEvent	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent interface represents simple user interface events.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent
UIEvent.cancelBubble	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent.cancelBubble property indicates if event bubbling for this event has been canceled or not. It is set to false by default, allowing the event to bubble up the DOM, if it is a bubbleable event. Setting this property to true stops the event from bubbling up the DOM. Not all events are allowed to bubble up the DOM.</p><pre><code>event.cancelBubble = bool;\nvar bool = event.cancelBubble;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/cancelBubble
UIEvent.detail	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent.detail read-only property, when non-zero, provides the current (or next, depending on the event) click count.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/detail
UIEvent.initUIEvent()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent.initUIEvent() method initializes a UI event once it's been created.</p><pre><code>event.initUIEvent(type, canBubble, cancelable, view, detail) \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/initUIEvent
UIEvent.isChar	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent.isChar read-only property returns a Boolean indicating whether the event produced a key character or not.</p><pre><code>bool = event.isChar;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/isChar
UIEvent.layerX	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent.layerX read-only property returns the horizontal coordinate of the event relative to the current layer.</p><pre><code>var xpos = event.layerX&lt;html&gt;\n&lt;head&gt;\n&lt;title&gt;pageX\pageY &amp; layerX\layerY example&lt;/title&gt;\n\n&lt;script type="text/javascript"&gt;\n\nfunction showCoords(evt){\n  var form = document.forms.form_coords;\n  var parent_id = evt.target.parentNode.id;\n  form.parentId.value = parent_id;\n  form.pageXCoords.value = evt.pageX;\n  form.pageYCoords.value = evt.pageY;\n  form.layerXCoords.value = evt.layerX;\n  form.layerYCoords.value = evt.layerY;\n}\n&lt;/script&gt;\n\n&lt;style type="text/css"&gt;\n\n #d1 {\n  border: solid blue 1px;\n  padding: 20px;\n }\n\n #d2 {\n  position: absolute;\n  top: 180px;\n  left: 80%;\n  right:auto;\n  width: 40%;\n  border: solid blue 1px;\n  padding: 20px;\n }\n\n #d3 {\n  position: absolute;\n  top: 240px;\n  left: 20%;\n  width: 50%;\n  border: solid blue 1px;\n  padding: 10px;\n }\n\n&lt;/style&gt;\n&lt;/head&gt;\n\n&lt;body onmousedown="showCoords(event)"&gt;\n\n&lt;p&gt;To display the mouse coordinates please click anywhere on the page.&lt;/p&gt;\n\n&lt;div id="d1"&gt;\n&lt;span&gt;This is an un-positioned div so clicking it will return\nlayerX/layerY values almost the same as pageX/PageY values.&lt;/span&gt;\n&lt;/div&gt;\n\n&lt;div id="d2"&gt;\n\n&lt;span&gt;This is a positioned div so clicking it will return layerX/layerY\nvalues that are relative to the top-left corner of this positioned\nelement. Note the pageX\pageY properties still return the\nabsolute position in the document, including page scrolling.&lt;/span&gt;\n\n&lt;span&gt;Make the page scroll more! This is a positioned div so clicking it\nwill return layerX/layerY values that are relative to the top-left\ncorner of this positioned element. Note the pageX\pageY properties still\nreturn the absolute position in the document, including page\nscrolling.&lt;/span&gt;\n\n&lt;/div&gt;\n\n&lt;div id="d3"&gt;\n&lt;form name="form_coords" id="form1"&gt;\n Parent Element id: &lt;input type="text" name="parentId" size="7" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\n pageX:&lt;input type="text" name="pageXCoords" size="7" /&gt;&#160;&#160;\n pageY:&lt;input type="text" name="pageYCoords" size="7" /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\n layerX:&lt;input type="text" name="layerXCoords" size="7" /&gt;&#160;&#160;\n layerY:&lt;input type="text" name="layerYCoords" size="7" /&gt;\n&lt;/form&gt;\n&lt;/div&gt;\n\n&lt;/body&gt;\n&lt;/html&gt;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/layerX
UIEvent.layerY	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent.layerY read-only property returns the vertical coordinate of the event relative to the current layer.</p><pre><code>var ypos = event.layerY;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/layerY
UIEvent.pageX	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The UIEvent.pageX read-only property returns the horizontal coordinate of the event relative to the whole document.</p><pre><code>var pos = event.pageXvar pageX = event.pageX;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/UIEvent/pageX

URL.createObjectURL()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The URL.createObjectURL() static method creates a DOMString containing an URL representing the object given in parameter. The URL lifetime is tied to the document in the window on which it was created. The new object URL represents the specified File object or Blob object.</p><pre><code>objectURL = URL.createObjectURL(blob);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/createObjectURL

URL.revokeObjectURL()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The URL.revokeObjectURL() static method releases an existing object URL which was previously created by calling URL.createObjectURL().&#160; Call this method when you've finished using a object URL, in order to let the browser know it doesn't need to keep the reference to the file any longer.</p><pre><code>window.URL.revokeObjectURL(objectURL);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/revokeObjectURL

If there were several matching values, this method deletes the others. If the search parameter doesn't exist, this method creates it.</p><pre><code>URLSearchParams.set(name, value)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URLSearchParams/set

URLUtilsReadOnly.origin	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The URLUtilsReadOnly.origin read-only property is a DOMString containing the Unicode serialization of the origin of the represented URL, that is, for http and https, the scheme followed by '://', followed by the domain, followed by ':', followed by the port (the default port, 80 and 443 respectively, if explicitely specified). VRDisplay	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The VRDisplay interface of the WebVR API represents any VR device supported by this API. VRDisplay.depthFar	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The depthFar property of the VRDisplay interface gets and sets the z-depth defining the far plane of the eye view frustum, i.e. the furthest viewable boundary of the scene.</p><pre><code>var mydepthFar = vrDisplayInstance.depthFar;\n\nvrDisplayInstance.depthFar = 7500.0;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/depthFar

VRDisplay.displayId	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The displayId read-only property of the VRDisplay interface returns an identifier for this particular VRDisplay, which is also used as an association point in the Gamepad API (see Gamepad.displayId).</p><pre><code>var myDisplayID = vrDisplayInstance.displayId;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/displayId
VRDisplay.displayName	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The displayName read-only property of the VRDisplay interface returns a human-readable name to identify the VRDisplay.</p><pre><code>var myDisplayName = vrDisplayInstance.displayName;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/displayName
VRDisplay.exitPresent()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The exitPresent() method of the VRDisplay interface stops the VRDisplay presenting a scene.</p><pre><code>vrDisplayInstance.exitPresent().then(function() {\n  // Do something after the presentation has ended\n});\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/exitPresent
VRDisplay.getEyeParameters()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The getEyeParameters() method of the VRDisplay interface returns the VREyeParameters object containing the eye parameters for the specified eye.</p><pre><code>var myEyeParameters = vrDisplayInstance.getEyeParameters(whichEye);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/getEyeParameters
VRDisplay.getImmediatePose()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The getImmediatePose() method of the VRDisplay interface returns a VRPose object defining the current pose of the VRDisplay, with no prediction applied.</p><pre><code>var myImmediatePose = vrDisplayInstance.getImmediatePose();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/getImmediatePose
VRDisplay.getLayers()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The getLayers() method of the VRDisplay interface returns the layers currently being presented by the VRDisplay.</p><pre><code>var myLayers = vrDisplayInstance.getLayers();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/getLayers
VRDisplay.getPose()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The getPose() method of the VRDisplay interface returns a VRPose object defining the future predicted pose of the VRDisplay as it will be when the current frame is actually presented.</p><pre><code>var myPose = vrDisplayInstance.getPose();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/getPose
VRdisplay.isConnected	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The isConnected read-only property of the VRDisplay interface returns a Boolean indicating whether the VRDisplay is connected to the computer.</p><pre><code>var isItConnected = vrDisplayInstance.isConnected;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/isConnected
VRDisplay.isPresenting	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The isPresenting read-only property of the VRDisplay interface returns a Boolean indicating whether the VRDisplay is currently having content presented through it.</p><pre><code>var isItPresenting = vrDisplayInstance.isPresenting;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/isPresenting
VRDisplay.requestAnimationFrame()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The requestAnimationFrame() method of the VRDisplay interface is a special implementation of Window.requestAnimationFrame containing a callback function that will be called every time a new frame of the VRDisplay presentation is rendered:</p><pre><code>var handle = vrDisplayInstance.requestAnimationFrame(callback);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/requestAnimationFrame

VRDevice.resetPose()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The resetPose() method of the VRDisplay interface resets the pose for the VRDisplay, treating its current VRPose.position and VRPose.orientation as the "origin/zero" values.</p><pre><code>vrDisplayInstance.resetPose();\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/VRDisplay/resetPose

WebGL2RenderingContext.drawArraysInstanced()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGL2RenderingContext.drawArraysInstanced() method of the WebGL 2 API renders primitives from array data like the gl.drawArrays() method. In addition, it can execute multiple instances of the range of elements.</p><pre><code>void gl.drawArraysInstanced(mode, first, count, instanceCount);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL2RenderingContext/drawArraysInstanced
WebGL2RenderingContext.drawBuffers()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGL2RenderingContext.drawBuffers() method of the WebGL 2 API defines draw buffers to which fragment colors are written into. The draw buffer settings are part of the state of the currently bound framebuffer or the drawingbuffer if no framebuffer is bound.</p><pre><code>void gl.drawBuffers(buffers);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL2RenderingContext/drawBuffers
WebGL2RenderingContext.drawElementsInstanced()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGL2RenderingContext.drawElementsInstanced() method of the WebGL 2 API renders primitives from array data like the gl.drawElements() method. In addition, it can execute multiple instances of a set of elements.</p><pre><code>void gl.drawElementsInstanced(mode, count, type, offset, instanceCount);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL2RenderingContext/drawElementsInstanced

WebGLRenderingContext.bindFramebuffer()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.bindFramebuffer() method of the WebGL API binds a given WebGLFramebuffer to a target.</p><pre><code>void gl.bindFramebuffer(target, framebuffer);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/bindFramebuffer
WebGLRenderingContext.bindRenderbuffer()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.bindRenderbuffer() method of the WebGL API binds a given WebGLRenderbuffer to a target, which must be gl.RENDERBUFFER.</p><pre><code>void gl.bindRenderbuffer(target, renderbuffer);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/bindRenderbuffer
WebGLRenderingContext.bindTexture()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.bindTexture() method of the WebGL API binds a given WebGLTexture to a target (binding point).</p><pre><code>void gl.bindTexture(target, texture);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/bindTexture
WebGLRenderingContext.blendColor()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.blendColor() method of the WebGL API is used to set the source and destination blending factors.</p><pre><code>void gl.blendColor(red, green, blue, alpha);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/blendColor
WebGLRenderingContext.blendEquation()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.blendEquation() method of the WebGL API is used to set both the RGB blend equation and alpha blend equation to a single equation.</p><pre><code>void gl.blendEquation(mode);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/blendEquation
WebGLRenderingContext.blendEquationSeparate()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.blendEquationSeparate() method of the WebGL API is used to set the RGB blend equation and alpha blend equation separately.</p><pre><code>void gl.blendEquationSeparate(modeRGB, modeAlpha);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/blendEquationSeparate
WebGLRenderingContext.blendFunc()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.blendFunc() method of the WebGL API defines which function is used for blending pixel arithmetic.</p><pre><code>void gl.blendFunc(sfactor, dfactor);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/blendFunc
WebGLRenderingContext.blendFuncSeparate()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.blendFuncSeparate() method of the WebGL API defines which function is used for blending pixel arithmetic for RGB and alpha components separately.</p><pre><code>void gl.blendFuncSeparate(srcRGB, dstRGB, srcAlpha, dstAlpha);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/blendFuncSeparate
WebGLRenderingContext.bufferData()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.bufferData() method of the WebGL API initializes and creates the buffer object's data store.</p><pre><code>void gl.bufferData(target, size, usage);\nvoid gl.bufferData(target, data, usage);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/bufferData
WebGLRenderingContext.bufferSubData()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.bufferSubData() method of the WebGL API updates a subset of a buffer object's data store.</p><pre><code>void gl.bufferSubData(target, offset, data);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/bufferSubData
WebGLRenderingContext.canvas	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebGLRenderingContext.canvas property is a read-only reference to the HTMLCanvasElement or OffscreenCanvas object that is associated with the context. It might be null if it is not associated with a canvas element or an OffscreenCanvas object.</p><pre><code>gl.canvas;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/canvas

Until now, it's simply redrawing everything exactly the same way every time. It's time to change that, so that our square actually moves.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/Tutorial/Animating_objects_with_WebGL

Creating 3D objects using WebGL	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Let's take our square into three dimensions by adding five more faces to create a cube. To do this efficiently, we're going to switch from drawing using the vertices directly by calling the gl.drawArrays() method to using the vertex array as a table, and referencing individual vertices in that table to define the positions of each face's vertices, by calling gl.drawElements().</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/Tutorial/Creating_3D_objects_using_WebGL
Getting started with WebGL	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WebGL enables web content to use an API based on OpenGL ES 2.0 to perform 3D rendering in an HTML canvas in browsers that support it without the use of plug-ins. WebGL programs consist of control code written in JavaScript and special effects code(shader code) that is executed on a computer's Graphics Processing Unit (GPU). WebGL elements can be mixed with other HTML elements and composited with other parts of the page or page background.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/Tutorial/Getting_started_with_WebGL
Lighting in WebGL	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The first thing to understand about WebGL is that unlike the broader OpenGL standard, WebGL does not have inherent support for lighting. You have to do it yourself. Fortunately, it's not all that hard to do, and this article will cover some of the basics.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/Tutorial/Lighting_in_WebGL

A complete list of extensions is available in the khronos webgl extension registry.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/Using_Extensions
WebGL best practices	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This article offers suggestions and tips to improve your WebGL content. WebGL model view projection	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This article explores how to take data within a WebGL project, and project it into the proper spaces to display it on the screen. It assumes a knowledge of basic matrix math using translation, scale, and rotation matrices. It explains the three core matrices that are typically used to represent a 3D object: the model, view and projection matrices.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGL_API/WebGL_model_view_projection

WebRTC API	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WebRTC (Web Real-Time Communications) is a technology which enables Web applications and sites to capture and optionally stream audio and/or video media, as well as to exchange arbitrary data between browsers without requiring an intermediary.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API
Improving compatibility using WebRTC adapter.js	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WebRTC organization provides on GitHub the WebRTC adapter to work around compatibility issues in different browsers' WebRTC implementations. The adapter is a JavaScript shim which lets your code to be written to the specification so that it will "just work" in all browsers with WebRTC support.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/adapter.js
WebRTC architecture overview	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Beneath the APIs that developers use to create and use WebRTC connections lie a number of network protocols and connectivity standards. This brief overview covers these standards.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Architecture
WebRTC coding guide	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Once you have an overall understanding of what WebRTC does and how it works, your mind likely turns to implementation. How do you create a Web application that uses two-way video or data streams without having to do all the hard work of compressing frames, building streams, and so forth by yourself? This coding guide will explain in depth how WebRTC works, and will dive into actual code that uses WebRTC to do useful things.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Coding_guide
WebRTC connectivity	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This article describes how the various WebRTC-related protocols interact with one another in order to create a connection and transfer data and/or media among peers.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Connectivity
High-level guides	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WebRTC (Web Real-Time Communications) is a broad, multi-component system for setting up and operating complex audio, video, and data channels across networks among two or more peers on the Web. The high-level guides listed below introduce WebRTC technology from a top-down perspective, describing the overall architecture, the life cycle of a WebRTC connection, and basic security and technological issues you might run into as you explore and build Web content or apps using the WebRTC API.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/High-level_guide
WebRTC API overview	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WebRTC consists of several interrelated APIs and protocols which work together to support the exchange of data and media between two or more peers. This article provides a brief overview of each of these APIs and what purpose it serves.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Overview
WebRTC protocols	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This article introduces the protocols on top of which the WebRTC API is built.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Protocols
Lifetime of a WebRTC session	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WebRTC lets you build peer-to-peer communication of arbitrary data, audio, or video—or any combination thereof—into a browser application. In this article, we'll look at the lifetime of a WebRTC session, from establishing the connection all the way through closing the connection when it's no longer needed.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Session_lifetime
Signaling and video calling	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Although WebRTC is billed as a fully peer-to-peer technology for the real-time exchange of audio, video, and data, there is one caveat. As discussed elsewhere, in order for two devices on different networks to locate one another, some form of discovery and media format negotiation must take place. This process, called signaling, involves both devices connecting to a third, mutually agreed-upon server through which the two devices can locate one another and exchange the needed negotiation messages.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Signaling_and_video_calling
A simple RTCDataChannel sample	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The RTCDataChannel interface is a feature of the WebRTC API which lets you open a channel between two peers over which you may send and receive arbitrary data. The API is intentionally similar to the WebSocket API, so that the same programming model can be used for each.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Simple_RTCDataChannel_sample

Using WebRTC data channels	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Once you've established a WebRTC peer connection using the RTCPeerConnection interface, you're able to send and receive media data between the two peers on the connection. But there's a lot more you can do with WebRTC. In this guide, we'll examine how to add a data channel to a peer connection, which can then be used to exchange arbitrary data; that is, any kind of data we wish, in any format we choose.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API/Using_data_channels

Web Audio API	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Web Audio API involves handling audio operations inside an audio context, and has been designed to allow modular routing. Basic audio operations are performed with audio nodes, which are linked together to form an audio routing graph. Several sources — with different types of channel layout — are supported even within a single context. This modular design provides the flexibility to create complex audio functions with dynamic effects.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Audio_API
Basic concepts behind Web Audio API	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This article explains some of the audio theory behind how the features of the Web Audio API work. It won't turn you into a master sound engineer, but it will give you enough background to understand why the Web Audio API works like it does, and allow you to make better informed decisions while developing with it.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Audio_API/Basic_concepts_behind_Web_Audio_API
Porting webkitAudioContext code to standards based AudioContext	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Web Audio standard was first implemented in WebKit, and the implementation was built in parallel with the work on the specification of the API.  As the specification evolved and changes were made to the spec, some of the old implementation pieces were not removed from the WebKit (and Blink) implementations due to backwards compatibility reasons.  New engines implementing the Web Audio spec (such as Gecko) will only implement the official, final version of the specification, which means that code using webkitAudioContext or old naming conventions in the Web Audio specification may not immediately work out of the box in a compliant Web Audio implementation.  This article attempts to summarize the areas where developers are likely to encounter these problems and provide examples on how to port such code to standards based AudioContext, which will work across different browser engines.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Audio_API/Porting_webkitAudioContext_code_to_standards_based_AudioContext
Using the Web Audio API	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Web Audio API provides a simple yet powerful mechanism to implement and manipulate audio content inside web applications. It allows you to develop complex audio mixing, effects, panning and more. In this article we will explain the basics of using the Web Audio API, via a couple of fairly simple examples.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Audio_API/Using_Web_Audio_API

Using the Web Storage API	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Storage objects are simple key-value stores, similar to objects, but they stay intact through page loads.  The keys and the values are always strings (note that integer keys will be automatically converted to strings, just like what object do). You can access these values like an object, or with the getItem() and setItem() methods.  These three lines all set the colorSetting entry in the same way:</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Storage_API/Using_the_Web_Storage_API
WebVTT	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WebVTT is a format for displaying timed text tracks (e.g. subtitles or captions) with the track element. The primary purpose of WebVTT files is to add text overlays to a video. WebVTT is a text based format, which must be encoded in UTF-8 format. Where you can use spaces you can also use tabs.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Video_Text_Tracks_Format
Web Workers API	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Web Workers are a mechanism by which a script operation can be made to run in a background thread separate from the main execution thread of a web application. The advantage of this is that laborious processing can be performed in a separate thread, allowing the main (usually the UI) thread to run without being blocked/slowed down.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API
Functions and classes available to Web Workers	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>In addition to the standard JavaScript set of functions (such as String, Array, Object, JSON etc), there are a variety of functions available from the DOM to workers. This article provides a list of those.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Functions_and_classes_available_to_workers
The structured clone algorithm	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The structured clone algorithm is a new algorithm defined by the HTML5 specification for serializing complex JavaScript objects. It's more capable than JSON in that it supports the serialization of objects that contain cyclic graphs — objects can refer to objects that refer to other objects in the same graph. In addition, in some cases, the structured clone algorithm may be more efficient than JSON.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Structured_clone_algorithm
Using Web Workers	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A worker is an object created using a constructor (e.g. Worker()) that runs a named JavaScript file — this file contains the code that will run in the worker thread; workers run in another global context that is different from the current window. Thus, using the window shortcut to get the current global scope (instead of self) within a Worker will return an error.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API/Using_web_workers
WheelEvent	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WheelEvent interface represents events that occur due to the user moving a mouse wheel or similar input device.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent
WheelEvent.deltaMode	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WheelEvent.deltaMode read-only property returns an unsigned long representing the unit of the delta values scroll amount. Permitted values are:</p><pre><code>var unit = event.deltaMode;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaMode
WheelEvent.deltaX	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WheelEvent.deltaX read-only property is a double representing the horizontal scroll amount in the WheelEvent.deltaMode unit.</p><pre><code>var dX = event.deltaX;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaX
WheelEvent.deltaY	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WheelEvent.deltaY read-only property is a double representing the vertical scroll amount in the WheelEvent.deltaMode unit.</p><pre><code>var dY = event.deltaY;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaY

Window.caches	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.caches read-only property returns the CacheStorage object associated with the current origin. This object enables service worker functionality such as storing assets for offline use, and generating custom responses to requests.</p><pre><code>var myCacheStorage = window.caches;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/caches

Window.console	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.console read-only property returns a reference to the Console object, which provides methods for logging information to the browser's console. These methods are intended for debugging purposes only and should not be relied on for presenting information to end users.</p><pre><code>var consoleObj = window.console;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/console
Window.content	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns a Window object for the primary content window. This is useful in XUL windows that have a browser (or tabbrowser or iframe) with type="content-primary" attribute on it - the most famous example is Firefox main window, browser.xul. In such cases, content returns a reference to the Window object for the document currently displayed in the browser. It is a shortcut for browserRef.contentWindow.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/content

Window.convertPointFromPageToNode	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Converts a Point object from coordinates based on the page to coordinates based on the given CSS node.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/convertPointFromPageToNode

This object allows web pages access to certain cryptographic related services.</p><pre><code>var cryptoObj = window.crypto || window.msCrypto; // for IE 11\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/crypto

The only difference is that, while data stored in localStorage has no expiration time, data stored in sessionStorage gets cleared when the browsing session ends—that is, when the browser is closed.</p><pre><code>myStorage = localStorage;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/localStorage

This value should be used instead of, for example, Date.now(), because this value will be the same for all animations started in this window during this refresh interval, allowing them to remain in sync with one another.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/mozAnimationStartTime

These events occur when the device sensor detects that an object becomes closer to or farther from the device.</p><pre><code>window.onuserproximity = funcRef</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/ondeviceproximity
Window.oninstall	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The oninstall property of the Window interface represent the event handler for the install event, which is thrown each time the page is successfully installed as a web app.</p><pre><code>window.oninstall = function(event) { ... };\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/oninstall

Not working in Gecko-based applications currently, see Notes section!</p><pre><code>window.onpaint =funcRef;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/onpaint
Window.onuserproximity	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.onuserproxymity property represents an EventHandler, that is a function to be called when the userproximity event occurs. These events are of type UserProximityEvent and occur when the the device sensor detects that an object becomes nearby.</p><pre><code>window.onuserproximity = eventHandler</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/onuserproximity
Window.onvrdisplayconnected	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onvrdisplayconnected property of the SpeechSynthesis interface represents an event handler that will run when a compatible VR device has been connected to the computer (when the vrdisplayconnected event fires).</p><pre><code>window.onvrdisplayconnected = function() { ... };\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/onvrdisplayconnected
Window.onvrdisplaydisconnected	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onvrdisplaydisconnected event handler property of the Window interface is called when a compatible VR device has been disconnected from the computer (when the vrdisplaydisconnected event fires).</p><pre><code>window.onvrdisplaydisconnected = function() { ... };\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/onvrdisplaydisconnected
Window.onvrdisplaypresentchange	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onvrdisplaypresentchange property of the SpeechSynthesis interface represents an event handler that will run when the presenting state of a VR device changes — i.e. goes from presenting to not presenting, or vice versa (when the onvrdisplaypresentchange event fires).</p><pre><code>window.onvrdisplaypresentchange = function() { ... };\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/onvrdisplaypresentchange

Window.openDialog()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>window.openDialog() is an extension to window.open(). It behaves the same, except that it can optionally take one or more parameters past windowFeatures, and windowFeatures itself is treated a little differently.</p><pre><code>newWindow = openDialog(url, name, features, arg1, arg2, ...) \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/openDialog

Window.outerWidth	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Window.outerWidth gets the width of the outside of the browser window. Window.personalbar	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns the personalbar object, whose visibility can be toggled in the window.</p><pre><code>objRef =window.personalbar\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/personalbar
Window.postMessage()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The window.postMessage method safely enables cross-origin communication. Normally, scripts on different pages are allowed to access each other if and only if the pages that executed them are at locations with the same protocol (usually both https), port number (443 being the default for https), and host (modulo document.domain being set by both pages to the same value). window.postMessage provides a controlled mechanism to circumvent this restriction in a way which is secure when properly used.</p><pre><code>otherWindow.postMessage(message, targetOrigin, [transfer]);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage
Window.print()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Opens the Print Dialog to print the current document.</p><pre><code>window.print() \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/print
Window.prompt()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.prompt() displays a dialog with an optional message prompting the user to input some text.</p><pre><code>result = window.prompt(message, default);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/prompt
Window.releaseEvents()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Releases the window from trapping events of a specific type.</p><pre><code>window.releaseEvents(eventType) \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/releaseEvents
window.requestAnimationFrame()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>You should call this method whenever you're ready to update your animation onscreen. This will request that your animation function be called before the browser performs the next repaint. The number of callbacks is usually 60 times per second, but will generally match the display refresh rate in most web browsers as per W3C recommendation. The callback rate may be reduced to a lower rate when running in background tabs or in hidden iframe s in order to improve performance and battery life.</p><pre><code>window.requestAnimationFrame(callback);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/requestAnimationFrame
requestIdleCallback	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The w indow.requestIdleCallback() method queues a function to be called during a browser's idle periods. This enables developers to perform background and low priority work on the main event loop, without impacting latency-critical events such as animation and input response. Functions are generally called in first-in-first-out order unless the function's timeout is reached before the browser calls it.</p><pre><code>var handle = window.requestIdleCallback(callback[, options])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/requestIdleCallback
Window.resizeBy()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Resizes the current window by a certain amount.</p><pre><code>window.resizeBy(xDelta, yDelta) \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/resizeBy
Window.resizeTo()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Dynamically resizes window.</p><pre><code>window.resizeTo(aWidth, aHeight) \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/resizeTo
Window.restore()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This method is currently not working, but you can use:</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/restore
Window.screen	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns a reference to the screen object associated with the window. The screen object, implementing the Screen interface, is a special object for inspecting properties of the screen on which the current window is being rendered.</p><pre><code>screenObj = window.screen;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/screen
Window.screenX	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.screenX read-only property returns the horizontal distance, in CSS pixels, of the left border of the user's browser from the left side of the screen.</p><pre><code>lLoc = window.screenX \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/screenX
Window.screenY	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.screenY read-only property returns the vertical distance, in CSS pixels of the top border of the user's browser from the top edge of the screen.</p><pre><code>lLoc = window.screenY \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/screenY
Window.scroll()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Scrolls the window to a particular place in the document.</p><pre><code>window.scroll(x-coord, y-coord) \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scroll
Window.scrollbars	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns the scrollbars object, whose visibility can be checked.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollbars
Window.scrollBy()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Scrolls the document in the window by the given amount.</p><pre><code>window.scrollBy(X, Y);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollBy

Window.scrollByPages()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Scrolls the current document by the specified number of pages.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollByPages
Window.scrollMaxX	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns the maximum number of pixels that the document can be scrolled horizontally.</p><pre><code>xpix = window.scrollMaxX\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollMaxX
Window.scrollMaxY	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns the maximum number of pixels that the document can be scrolled vertically.</p><pre><code>ypix = window.scrollMaxY\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollMaxY
Window.scrollTo()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Scrolls to a particular set of coordinates in the document.</p><pre><code>window.scrollTo(x-coord, y-coord)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollTo
Window.scrollX	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns the number of pixels that the document has already been scrolled horizontally.</p><pre><code>var x = window.scrollX;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollX
Window.scrollY	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns the number of pixels that the document has already been scrolled vertically.</p><pre><code>var y = window.scrollY;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollY
Window.self	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.self read-only property returns the window itself, as a WindowProxy. It can be used with dot notation on a window object (that is, window.self) or standalone (self). The advantage of the standalone notation is that a similar notation exists for non-window contexts, such as in Web Workers. By using self, you can refer to the global scope in a way that will work not only in a window context (self will resolve to window.self) but also in a worker context (self will then resolve to WorkerGlobalScope.self).</p><pre><code>var w = window.self;  // w === window\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/self
Window.sessionStorage	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The sessionStorage property allows you to access a session Storage object. sessionStorage is similar to Window.localStorage, the only difference is while data stored in localStorage has no expiration set, data stored in sessionStorage gets cleared when the page session ends. A page session lasts for as long as the browser is open and survives over page reloads and restores. Opening a page in a new tab or window will cause a new session to be initiated, which differs from how session cookies work.</p><pre><code>// Save data to sessionStorage\nsessionStorage.setItem('key', 'value');\n\n// Get saved data from sessionStorage\nvar data = sessionStorage.getItem('key');\n\n// Remove saved data from sessionStorage\nsessionStorage.removeItem('key')\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/sessionStorage
Window.setCursor()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Changes the cursor for the current window.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/setCursor
Window.setImmediate()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This method is used to break up long running operations and run a callback function immediately after the browser has completed other operations such as events and display updates.</p><pre><code>var immediateID = setImmediate(func, [param1, param2, ...]);\nvar immediateID = setImmediate(func);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/setImmediate
Window.showModalDialog()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.showModalDialog() creates and displays a modal dialog box containing a specified HTML document.</p><pre><code>returnVal = window.showModalDialog(uri[, arguments][, options]);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/showModalDialog
Window.sidebar	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns a sidebar object, which contains several methods for registering add-ons with browser.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/sidebar
Window.sizeToContent()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.sizeToContent() method sizes the window according to its content. In order for it to work, the DOM content should be loaded when this function is called, for example once the DOMContentLoaded event has been thrown.</p><pre><code>window.sizeToContent() \n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/sizeToContent
Window.speechSynthesis	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The speechSynthesis read-only property of the Window object returns a SpeechSynthesis object, which is the entry point into using Web Speech API speech synthesis functionality.</p><pre><code>var synth = window.speechSynthesis;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/speechSynthesis
Window.status	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Sets the text in the status bar at the bottom of the browser or returns the previously set text.</p><pre><code>window.status = string;\nvar value = window.status;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/status

Window.top	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Returns a reference to the topmost window in the window hierarchy.</p><pre><code>var topWindow = window.top;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/top
