Window.URL	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.URL property returns an object that provides static methods used for creating and managing object URLs. It can also be called as a constructor to construct URL objects.</p><pre><code>img.src = URL.createObjectURL(blob);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/URL
Window.window	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The window property of a window object points to the window object itself. Thus the following expressions all return the same window object:</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/window
Window.windowState	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Check for window state:</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/windowState
WindowBase64	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowBase64 helper contains utility methods to convert data to and from base64, a binary-to-text encoding scheme. For example it is used in data URIs.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowBase64
WindowBase64.atob()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowBase64.atob() function decodes a string of data which has been encoded using base-64 encoding. You can use the window.btoa() method to encode and transmit data which may otherwise cause communication problems, then transmit it and use the window.atob() method to decode the data again. For example, you can encode, transmit, and decode control characters such as ASCII values 0 through 31.</p><pre><code>var decodedData = window.atob(encodedData);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowBase64/atob
Base64 encoding and decoding	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Base64 is a group of similar binary-to-text encoding schemes that represent binary data in an ASCII string format by translating it into a radix-64 representation. The term Base64 originates from a specific MIME content transfer encoding.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowBase64/Base64_encoding_and_decoding
WindowBase64.btoa()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowBase64.btoa() method creates a base-64 encoded ASCII string from a String object in which each character in the string is treated as a byte of binary data.</p><pre><code>var encodedData = window.btoa(stringToEncode);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowBase64/btoa
WindowClient	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowClient interface of the ServiceWorker API represents the scope of a service worker client that is a document in a browser context, controlled by an active worker. The service worker client independently selects and uses a service worker for its own loading and sub-resources.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowClient
WindowClient.focus()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The focus() method of the WindowClient interface gives user input focus to the current client and returns a Promise that resolves to the existing WindowClient.</p><pre><code>Client.focus().then(function(WindowClient) {\n  // do something with your WindowClient once it has been focused\n});</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowClient/focus
WindowClient.focused	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The focused read-only property of the WindowClient interface is a Boolean that indicates whether the current client has focus.</p><pre><code>myFocused = WindowClient.focused;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowClient/focused
WindowClient.navigate()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The navigate() method of the WindowClient interface loads a specified URL into a controlled client page then returns a Promise that resolves to the existing WindowClient.</p><pre><code>WindowClient.navigate(url).then(function(WindowClient) {\n  // do something with your WindowClient after navigation\n});</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowClient/navigate
WindowClient.visibilityState	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The visibilityState read-only property of the WindowClient interface indicates the visibility of the current client. This value can be one of hidden, visible, prerender, or unloaded.</p><pre><code>myVisState = WindowClient.visibilityState;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowClient/visibilityState
WindowEventHandlers	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WindowEventHandlers mixin describes the event handlers common to several interfaces like Window, or HTMLBodyElement and HTMLFrameSetElement. Each of these interfaces can implement additional specific event handlers.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers
WindowEventHandlers.onafterprint	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowEventHandlers.onafterprint property sets and returns the onafterprint EventHandler for the current window.</p><pre><code>window.onafterprint = event handling code\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onafterprint
WindowEventHandlers.onbeforeprint	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The property&#160;onbeforeprint sets and returns the onbeforeprint event handler code for the current window.</p><pre><code>window.onbeforeprint = event handling code\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onbeforeprint
WindowEventHandlers.onbeforeunload	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowEventHandlers.onbeforeunload event handler property contains the code executed when the beforeunload is sent. This event fires when a window is about to unload its resources. The document is still visible and the event is still cancelable.</p><pre><code>window.onbeforeunload = funcRef</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onbeforeunload
WindowEventHandlers.onhashchange	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The hashchange event fires when a window's hash changes (see location.hash).</p><pre><code>window.onhashchange = funcRef;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onhashchange
WindowEventHandlers.onlanguagechange	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowEventHandlers.onlanguagechange event handler is a property containing the code to execute when the languagechange event, of type Event, is received by the object implementing this interface, usually a Window, an HTMLBodyElement, or an HTMLIFrameElement. Such an event is sent by the browser to inform that the preferred languages list has been updated. The list is accessible via NavigatorLanguage.languages.</p><pre><code>object.onlanguagechange = function;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onlanguagechange
WindowEventHandlers.onpopstate	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>An event handler for the popstate event on the window.</p><pre><code>window.onpopstate = funcRef;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onpopstate
WindowEventHandlers.onrejectionhandled	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.onrejectionhandled property is an event handler for processing rejectionhandled events, which are raised when Promise s are rejected.</p><pre><code>window.addEventListener("rejectionhandled", function(event) { ... });\nwindow.onrejectionhandled = function(event) { ...};</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onrejectionhandled
WindowEventHandlers.onstorage	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WindowEventHandlers.onstorage property contains an event handler that runs when the storage event fires. This occurs when a storage area is changed (e.g. a new item is stored.)</p><pre><code>windowObj.onstorage = function() { ... };</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onstorage
WindowEventHandlers.onunhandledrejection	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Window.onunhandledrejection property is an event handler for processing unhandledrejection events, which are raised for unhandled Promise rejections.</p><pre><code>window.addEventListener("unhandledrejection", function(event) { ... });\nwindow.onunhandledrejection = function(event) { ...};</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onunhandledrejection
WindowEventHandlers.onunload	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The unload event is raised when the window is unloading its content and resources. The resources removal is processed after the unload event occurs.</p><pre><code>window.onunload = funcRef;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onunload
WindowTimers	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>WindowTimers is a mixin used to provide utility methods which set and clear timers. No objects of this type exist; instead, its methods are available on Window for the standard browsing scope, or on WorkerGlobalScope for workers.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers
WindowTimers.clearInterval()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Cancels a timed, repeating action which was previously established by a call to setInterval().</p><pre><code>window.clearInterval(intervalID)\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers/clearInterval
WindowTimers.clearTimeout()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Cancels a timeout previously established by calling setTimeout().</p><pre><code>window.clearTimeout(timeoutID)\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers/clearTimeout
WindowTimers.setInterval()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Repeatedly calls a function or executes a code snippet, with a fixed time delay between each call. Returns an intervalID.</p><pre><code>var intervalID = window.setInterval(func, delay[, param1, param2, ...]);\nvar intervalID = window.setInterval(code, delay);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers/setInterval
WindowTimers.setTimeout()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Sets a timer which executes a function or specified piece of code once after the timer expires.</p><pre><code>var timeoutID = window.setTimeout(func[, delay, param1, param2, ...]);\nvar timeoutID = window.setTimeout(code[, delay]);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowTimers/setTimeout
Worker	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Worker interface of the Web Workers API represents a background task that can be easily created and can send messages back to its creator. Creating a worker is as simple as calling the Worker() constructor and specifying a script to be run in the worker thread.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Worker
Worker.onmessage	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onmessage property of the Worker interface represents an EventHandler, that is a function to be called when the message event occurs. These events are of type MessageEvent and will be called when the worker's parent receives a message (i.e. from the DedicatedWorkerGlobalScope.postMessage method.</p><pre><code>myWorker.onmessage = function(e) { ... }</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Worker/onmessage
Worker.postMessage()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The postMessage() method of the Worker interface sends a message to the worker's inner scope. This accepts a single parameter, which is the data to send to the worker. The data may be any value or JavaScript object handled by the structured clone algorithm, which includes cyclical references.</p><pre><code>myWorker.postMessage(aMessage, transferList);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Worker/postMessage
Worker.terminate()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The terminate() method of the Worker interface immediately terminates the Worker. This does not offer the worker an opportunity to finish its operations; it is simply stopped at once.</p><pre><code>myWorker.terminate();</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Worker/terminate
Worker()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Worker() constructor creates a Worker object that executes the script at the specified URL. This script must obey the same-origin policy.</p><pre><code>var myWorker = new Worker("aURL");</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Worker/Worker
WorkerGlobalScope.caches	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The caches read-only property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface returns the CacheStorage object associated with the current worker context. This object enables service worker functionality such as storing assets for offline use, and generating custom responses to requests.</p><pre><code>var myCacheStorage = self.caches; // or just caches\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/caches
WorkerGlobalScope.close()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The close() method of the WorkerGlobalScope interface discards any tasks queued in the WorkerGlobalScope 's event loop, effectively closing this particular scope.</p><pre><code>self.close();</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/close
WorkerGlobalScope.console	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The console read-only property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface returns a Console object providing access to the browser console for the worker.</p><pre><code>var consoleObj = self.console;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/console
WorkerGlobalScope.dump()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The dump() method of the WorkerGlobalScope interface allows you to write a message to stdout — i.e. in your terminal, in Firefox only. This is the same as Firefox's window.dump, but for workers.</p><pre><code>dump('My message\n');</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/dump
WorkerGlobalScope.importScripts()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The importScripts() method of the WorkerGlobalScope interface synchronously imports one or more scripts into the worker's scope.</p><pre><code>self.importScripts('foo.js');\nself.importScripts('foo.js', 'bar.js', ...);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/importScripts
WorkerGlobalScope.location	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The location read-only property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface returns the WorkerLocation associated with the worker. It is a specific location object, mostly a subset of the Location for browsing scopes, but adapted to workers.</p><pre><code>var locationObj = self.location;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/location
WorkerGlobalScope.navigator	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The navigator read-only property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface returns the WorkerNavigator associated with the worker. It is a specific navigator object, mostly a subset of the Navigator for browsing scopes, but adapted to workers.</p><pre><code>var navigatorObj = self.navigator;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/navigator
WorkerGlobalScope.onclose	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onclose property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface represents an EventHandler to be called when the close event occurs and bubbles through the Worker.</p><pre><code>self.onclose = function() { ... };</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/onclose
WorkerGlobalScope.onerror	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onerror property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface represents an EventHandler to be called when the error event occurs and bubbles through the Worker.</p><pre><code>self.onerror = function() { ... };</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/onerror
WorkerGlobalScope.onlanguagechange	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onlanguagechange property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface represents an EventHandler to be called when the languagechange event occurs and bubbles through the Worker.</p><pre><code>self.onlanguagechange = function() { ... };</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/onlanguagechange
WorkerGlobalScope.onoffline	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The onoffline property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface represents an EventHandler to be called when the offline event occurs and bubbles through the Worker.</p><pre><code>self.onoffline = function() { ... };</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/onoffline
WorkerGlobalScope.ononline	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The ononline property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface represents an EventHandler to be called when the online event occurs and bubbles through the Worker.</p><pre><code>self.ononline = function() { ... };</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/ononline
WorkerGlobalScope.performance	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The performance read-only property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface returns a Performance object to be used on the worker.</p><pre><code>var perfObj = self.performance;\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/performance
WorkerGlobalScope.self	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The self read-only property of the WorkerGlobalScope interface returns a reference to the WorkerGlobalScope itself. Most of the time it is a specific scope like DedicatedWorkerGlobalScope, SharedWorkerGlobalScope, or ServiceWorkerGlobalScope.</p><pre><code>var selfRef = self;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope/self
WorkerLocation	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WorkerLocation interface defines the absolute location of the script executed by the Worker. Such an object is initialized for each worker and is available via the WorkerGlobalScope.location property obtained by calling window.self.location.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerLocation
WorkerNavigator	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WorkerNavigator interface represents a subset of the Navigator interface allowed to be accessed from a Worker. Such an object is initialized for each worker and is available via the WorkerGlobalScope.navigator property obtained by calling window.self.navigator.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator
WorkerNavigator.permissions	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The WorkerNavigator.permissions read-only property returns a Permissions object that can be used to query and update permission status of APIs covered by the Permissions API.</p><pre><code>permissionsObj = self.permissions\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/permissions
WorkerNavigator.sendBeacon()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The NavigatorWorker.sendBeacon() method can be used to asynchronously transfer a small amount of data over HTTP from a worker to a web server. This is functionally equivalent to the Navigator.sendBeacon() method; see that article for additional details on what this method can be used for and why.</p><pre><code>self.navigator.sendBeacon(url, data);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/sendBeacon
XMLDocument	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLDocument interface represent an XML document. It inherits from the generic Document and does not add any specific methods or properties to it: nevertheless, several algorithms behave differently with the two types of documents.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLDocument
XMLDocument.load()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>document.load() is a part of an old version of the W3C DOM Level 3 Load & Save module. Can be used with document.async to indicate whether the request is synchronous or asynchronous (the default). As of at least Gecko 1.9, this no longer supports cross-site loading of documents (Use XMLHttpRequest instead).</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLDocument/load
XMLHttpRequest	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest is an API that provides client functionality for transferring data between a client and a server. It provides an easy way to retrieve data from a URL without having to do a full page refresh. This enables a Web page to update just a part of the page without disrupting what the user is doing.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest
XMLHttpRequest.abort()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.abort() method aborts the request if it has already been sent. When a request is aborted, its readyState is set to 0 (UNSENT), but the readystatechange event is not fired.</p><pre><code>xhrInstance.abort();</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/abort
XMLHttpRequest.channel	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest.channel is an nsIChannel that used by the object when performing the request. This is null if the channel hasn't been created yet. In the case of a multi-part request, this is the initial channel, not the different parts in the multi-part request. Requires elevated privileges to access.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/channel
XMLHttpRequest.getAllResponseHeaders()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.getAllResponseHeaders() method returns all the response headers, separated by CRLF, as a string, or null if no response has been received.</p><pre><code>var headers = request.getAllResponseHeaders();</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/getAllResponseHeaders
XMLHttpRequest.getResponseHeader()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.getResponseHeader() method returns the string containing the text of the specified header. If there are multiple response headers with the same name, then their values are returned as a single concatenated string, where each value is separated from the previous one by a pair of comma and space. The getResponseHeader() method returns the value as a UTF byte squence. The search for the header name is case-insensitive.</p><pre><code>var myHeader = getResponseHeader(name);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/getResponseHeader

The function is passed the channel property of an XMLHTTPRequest to extract the following information:</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/How_to_check_the_secruity_state_of_an_XMLHTTPRequest_over_SSL
HTML in XMLHttpRequest	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The W3C XMLHttpRequest specification adds HTML parsing support to XMLHttpRequest, which originally supported only XML parsing. This feature allows Web apps to obtain an HTML resource as a parsed DOM using XMLHttpRequest.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/HTML_in_XMLHttpRequest

XMLHttpRequest.mozAnon	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest.mozAnon is a boolean. If true, the request will be sent without cookie and authentication headers.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/mozAnon
XMLHttpRequest.mozBackgroundRequest	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest.mozBackgroundRequest is a boolean. Indicates whether or not the object represents a background service request. If true, no load group is associated with the request, and security dialogs are prevented from being shown to the user.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/mozBackgroundRequest
XMLHttpRequest.mozResponseArrayBuffer	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Is an ArrayBuffer. The response to the request, as a JavaScript typed array. This is NULL if the request was not successful, or if it hasn't been sent yet.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/mozResponseArrayBuffer
XMLHttpRequest.mozSystem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest is a boolean. If true, the same origin policy will not be enforced on the request.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/mozSystem
XMLHttpRequest.multipart	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Is a boolean. This Gecko-only feature was removed in Firefox/Gecko 22. Please use Server-Sent Events, Web Sockets, or responseText from progress events instead.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/multipart
XMLHttpRequest.onreadystatechange	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>An EventHandler that is called whenever the readyState attribute changes. The callback is called from the user interface thread. The XMLHttpRequest.onreadystatechange property contains the event handler to be called when the readystatechange event is fired, that is every time the readyState property of the XMLHttpRequest changes. The callback is called from the user interface thread.</p><pre><code>XMLHttpRequest.onreadystatechange = callback;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/onreadystatechange
XMLHttpRequest.open()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.open() method initializes a request. This method is to be used from JavaScript code; to initialize a request from native code, use openRequest() instead.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/open
XMLHttpRequest.openRequest()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Initializes a request. This method is to be used from native code; to initialize a request from JavaScript code, use open() instead. See the documentation for open().</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/openRequest
XMLHttpRequest.overrideMimeType()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.overrideMimeType() method overrides the MIME type returned by the server. This may be used, for example, to force a stream to be treated and parsed as text/xml, even if the server does not report it as such. This method must be called before send().</p><pre><code>// Needs content</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/overrideMimeType
XMLHttpRequest.readyState	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.readyState property returns the state an XMLHttpRequest client is in. An XHR client exists in one of the following states:</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/readyState
XMLHttpRequest.response	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.response property returns the response's body. It can be of the type ArrayBuffer, Blob, Document, JavaScript object, or a DOMString, depending of the value of XMLHttpRequest.responseType property. Value of response is null if the request is not complete or was not successful. However, if the value of responseType was set to "text" or the empty string, response can contain the partial text response while the request is still in the loading state.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/response
XMLHttpRequest.responseText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.responseText property returns a DOMString that contains the response to the request as text, or null if the request was unsuccessful or has not yet been sent. The responseText property will have the partial response as it arrives even before the request is complete. If responseType is set to anything other than the empty string or "text", accessing responseText will throw InvalidStateError exception.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/responseText
XMLHttpRequest.responseType	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.responseType property is an enumerated value that returns the type of the response. It also lets the author change the response type to one "arraybuffer", "blob", "document", "json", or "text". If an empty string is set as the value of responseType, it is assumed as type "text".</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/responseType
XMLHttpRequest.responseURL	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.responseURL property returns the serialized URL of the response or the empty string if the URL is null. If the URL is returned, URL fragment if present in the URL will be stripped away. The value of responseURL will be the final URL obtained after any redirects.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/responseURL
XMLHttpRequest.responseXML	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.responseXML property returns a Document containing the response to the request, or null if the request was unsuccessful, has not yet been sent, or cannot be parsed as XML or HTML. The response is parsed as if it were a text/xml stream. When the responseType is set to "document" and the request has been made asynchronously, the response is parsed as a text/html stream. responseXML is null for data: URLs.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/responseXML
XMLHttpRequest.send()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.send() method sends the request. If the request is asynchronous (which is the default), this method returns as soon as the request is sent. If the request is synchronous, this method doesn't return until the response has arrived. send() accepts an optional argument for the request body. If the request method is GET or HEAD, the argument is ignored and request body is set to null.</p><pre><code>void send();\nvoid send(ArrayBuffer data);\nvoid send(ArrayBufferView data);\nvoid send(Blob data);\nvoid send(Document data);\nvoid send(DOMString? data);\nvoid send(FormData data);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/send
XMLHttpRequest.sendAsBinary()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.sendAsBinary() method is a variant of the send() method that sends binary data.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/sendAsBinary
Sending and Receiving Binary Data	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The r esponseType property of the XMLHttpRequest object can be set to change the expected response type from the server. Possible values are the empty string (default), "arraybuffer", "blob", "document", "json", and "text". The response property will contain the entity body according to responseType, as an ArrayBuffer, Blob, Document, JSON, or string. This is null if the request is not complete or was not successful.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/Sending_and_Receiving_Binary_Data
XMLHttpRequest.setRequestHeader()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.setRequestHeader() method sets the value of an HTTP request header. You must call setRequestHeader() after open(), but before send(). If this method is called several times with the same header, the values are merged into one single request header.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/setRequestHeader
XMLHttpRequest.status	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.status property returns the numerical status code of the response of the XMLHttpRequest. status will be an unsigned short. Before the request is complete, the value of status will be 0. It is worth noting that browsers report a status of 0 in case of XMLHttpRequest errors too.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/status
XMLHttpRequest.statusText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.statusText property returns a DOMString containing the response's status message as returned by the HTTP server. Unlike XMLHTTPRequest.status which indicates a numerical status code, this property contains the text of the response status, such as "OK" or "Not Found". If the request's readyState is in UNSENT or OPENED state, the value of statusText will be an empty string.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/statusText
Synchronous and asynchronous requests	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest supports both synchronous and asynchronous communications. In general, however, asynchronous requests should be preferred to synchronous requests for performance reasons.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/Synchronous_and_Asynchronous_Requests
XMLHttpRequest.timeout	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.timeout property is an unsigned long representing the number of milliseconds a request can take before automatically being terminated. The default value is 0, which means there is no timeout. Timeout shouldn't be used for synchronous XMLHttpRequests requests used in a document environment or it will throw an InvalidAccessError exception. When a timeout happens, a timeout event is fired.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/timeout
XMLHttpRequest.upload	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.upload property returns an XMLHttpRequestUpload object, representing the upload process. It is an opaque object, but being an XMLHttpRequestEventTarget, event listeners can be set on it to track its process.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/upload
Using XMLHttpRequest	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest makes sending HTTP requests very easy.  You simply create an instance of the object, open a URL, and send the request.  The HTTP status of the result, as well as the result's contents, are available in the request object when the transaction is completed. This page outlines some of the common, and even slightly obscure, use cases for this powerful JavaScript object.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/Using_XMLHttpRequest
Using XMLHttpRequest in IE6	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequest was first introduced by Microsoft in Internet Explorer 5.0 as an ActiveX control. However, in IE7 and other browsers XMLHttpRequest is a native JavaScript object.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/Using_XMLHttpRequest_in_IE6
XMLHttpRequest.withCredentials	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequest.withCredentials property is a Boolean that indicates whether or not cross-site Access-Control requests should be made using credentials such as cookies, authorization headers or TLS client certificates. Setting withCredentials has no effect on same-site requests.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/withCredentials

XMLHttpRequestEventTarget	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>XMLHttpRequestEventTarget is the interface that describes the event handlers you can implement in an object that will handle events for an XMLHttpRequest.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequestEventTarget
XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onabort	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onabort is the function called when an XMLHttpRequest transaction is aborted, such as when the XMLHttpRequest.abort() function is called.</p><pre><code>XMLHttpRequest.onabort = callback;</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequestEventTarget/onabort

It has methods to load the XSLT stylesheet, to manipulate xsl:param parameter values, and to apply the transformation to documents.</p><pre><code>new XSLTProcessor()</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XSLTProcessor
XSLT Basic Example	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This first example demonstrates the basics of setting up an XSLT transformation in a browser. The example will take an XML document that contains information (title, list of authors and body text) about an article and present it in an human readable form.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XSLTProcessor/Basic_Example
Browser Differences	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Netscape 7.x (all platforms) and Internet Explorer 6 (Windows) support the W3C XSLT 1.0 standard (http://www.w3.org/TR/xslt). IE 5.0 and 5.5 (both Windows) supported only the working draft of XSLT, and thus are not compatible with XSLT 1.0 stylesheets. Netscape 6.x only partially supported XSLT 1.0.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XSLTProcessor/Browser_Differences
Generating HTML	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>One common application of XSLT in the browser is to transform XML into HTML on the client. The second example will transform the input document (example2.xml), which again contains information about an article, into an HTML document.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XSLTProcessor/Generating_HTML
Introduction	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>One noticeable trend in W3C standards has been the effort to separate content from style. This would allow the same style to be reused for multiple content, as well as simplify maintenance and allow a quick (only modify one file) way to change the look of content.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XSLTProcessor/Introduction
XSL Transformations in Mozilla FAQ	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Make sure the mime type for both source and stylesheet are set to an XML mimetype, namely text/xml or application/xml. The XSLT namespace is http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform. Use the ?xml-stylesheet ? processing instruction instead of the non-standard xml:stylesheet. The most common cause is the MIME type handling. To find out which MIME type your server sends, look at Page Info, use extensions like LiveHTTPHeaders or a download manager like wget. Mozilla won't load XSLT stylesheets from a different domain for security reasons.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XSLTProcessor/XSL_Transformations_in_Mozilla_FAQ
Classes	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>JavaScript classes are introduced in ECMAScript 6 are syntactical sugar over JavaScript's existing prototype-based inheritance. The class syntax is not introducing a new object-oriented inheritance model to JavaScript. JavaScript classes provide a much simpler and clearer syntax to create objects and deal with inheritance.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes
constructor	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The constructor method is a special method for creating and initializing an object created with a class.</p><p>There can only be one special method with the name "constructor" in a class. A SyntaxError will be thrown, if the class contains more than one occurrence of a constructor method.</p><pre><code>class Square extends Polygon {\n  constructor(length) {\n    // Here, it calls the parent class' constructor with lengths\n    // provided for the Polygon's width and height\n    super(length, length);\n    // Note: In derived classes, super() must be called before you\n    // can use 'this'. Leaving this out will cause a reference error.\n    this.name = 'Square';\n  }\n\n  get area() {\n    return this.height * this.width;\n  }\n\n  set area(value) {\n    this.area = value;\n  } \n}</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes/constructor
extends	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The extends keyword is used in a class declarations or class expressions to create a class with a child of another class.</p><p>The extends keyword can be used to subclass custom classes as well as built-in objects.</p><pre><code>class Square extends Polygon {\n  constructor(length) {\n    // Here, it calls the parent class' constructor with lengths\n    // provided for the Polygon's width and height\n    super(length, length);\n    // Note: In derived classes, super() must be called before you\n    // can use 'this'. Leaving this out will cause a reference error.\n    this.name = 'Square';\n  }\n\n  get area() {\n    return this.height * this.width;\n  }\n\n  set area(value) {\n&#160;   this.height = this.width = Math.sqrt(value);\n    this.area = value;\n  } \n}</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes/extends
static	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The static keyword defines a static method for a class.</p><p>Static methods are called without instantiating their class and&#160;are also not&#160;callable when the class is instantiated. Static methods are often used to create utility functions for an application.</p><pre><code>class StaticMethodCall {\n    static staticMethod() {\n        return 'Static method has been called';\n    }\n    static anotherStaticMethod() {\n        return this.staticMethod() + ' from another static method';\n    }\n}\nStaticMethodCall.staticMethod(); \n// 'Static method has been called'\n\nStaticMethodCall.anotherStaticMethod(); \n// 'Static method has been called from another static method'</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Classes/static
JavaScript error reference	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Errors, errors everywhere.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors
Warning: -file- is being assigned a //# sourceMappingURL, but already has one	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A source map has been specified more than once for a given JavaScript source.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Already_has_pragma
warning -file- is being assigned a //# sourcemappingurl but already has one	R	Warning: -file- is being assigned a //# sourceMappingURL, but already has one										
TypeError: invalid Array.prototype.sort argument	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The argument of Array.prototype.sort() is expected to be either undefined or a function which compares its operands.</p><pre><code>Invalid Cases:\nValid Cases:\n[1, 3, 2].sort();   // [1, 2, 3]\n\n\nvar cmp = { asc: (x, y) => x >= y, dsc : (x, y) => x <= y };\n[1, 3, 2].sort(cmp[this.key || 'asc']); // [1, 2, 3]\nValid Cases:\n[1, 3, 2].sort();   // [1, 2, 3]\n\n\nvar cmp = { asc: (x, y) => x >= y, dsc : (x, y) => x <= y };\n[1, 3, 2].sort(cmp[this.key || 'asc']); // [1, 2, 3]</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Array_sort_argument
typeerror invalid array prototype sort argument	R	TypeError: invalid Array.prototype.sort argument										
SyntaxError: "x" is not a legal ECMA-262 octal constant	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Decimal literals can start with a zero (0) followed by another decimal digit, but If all digits after the leading 0 are smaller than 8, the number is interpreted as an octal number. Because this is not the case with 08 and 09, JavaScript warns about it.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Bad_octal
syntaxerror x is not a legal ecma-262 octal constant	R	SyntaxError: "x" is not a legal ECMA-262 octal constant										
RangeError: radix must be an integer	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The optional radix parameter with the Number.prototype.toString() method has been used. This parameter must be an integer (a number) between 2 and 36 specifying the base of the number system to be used for representing numeric values.</p><pre><code>Invalid Cases:\nValid Cases:\n(42).toString(2);     // "101010" (binary)\n(13).toString(8);     // "15"     (octal)\n(0x42).toString(10);  // "66"     (decimal)\n(100000).toString(16) // "186a0"  (hexadecimal)\n\nValid Cases:\n(42).toString(2);     // "101010" (binary)\n(13).toString(8);     // "15"     (octal)\n(0x42).toString(10);  // "66"     (decimal)\n(100000).toString(16) // "186a0"  (hexadecimal)\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Bad_radix
rangeerror radix must be an integer	R	RangeError: radix must be an integer										
SyntaxError: return not in function	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A return or yield statement is called outside of a function. Maybe there are missing curly brackets somewhere? The return and yield statements must be in a function, because they end (or pause and resume) function execution and specify a value to be returned to the function caller.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Bad_return_or_yield
syntaxerror return not in function	R	SyntaxError: return not in function										
TypeError: property "x" is non-configurable and can't be deleted	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>It was attempted to delete a property, but that property is non-configurable. The configurable attribute controls whether the property can be deleted from the object and whether its attributes (other than writable) can be changed.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Cant_delete
typeerror property x is non-configurable and can't be deleted	R	TypeError: property "x" is non-configurable and can't be deleted										
ReferenceError: deprecated caller or arguments usage	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>In strict mode, the Function.caller or Function.arguments properties are used and shouldn't be. They are deprecated, because they leak the function caller, are non-standard, hard to optimize and potentially a performance-harmful feature.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Deprecated_caller_or_arguments_usage
referenceerror deprecated caller or arguments usage	R	ReferenceError: deprecated caller or arguments usage										
SyntaxError: Using //@ to indicate sourceURL pragmas is deprecated. SyntaxError: Malformed formal parameter	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>There is a Function() constructor with at least two arguments passed in the code. The last argument is the source code for the new function you're creating. All the rest make up your new function's argument list.</p><pre><code>Invalid Cases:\nValid Cases:\nvar f = Function("x, y", "return x + y;");  // correctly punctuated\n\nvar f = Function("x", "return x;");\n\n// if you can, avoid using Function - this is much faster\nvar f = function (x) { return x; };\n\nValid Cases:\nvar f = Function("x, y", "return x + y;");  // correctly punctuated\n\nvar f = Function("x", "return x;");\n\n// if you can, avoid using Function - this is much faster\nvar f = function (x) { return x; };\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Malformed_formal_parameter

RangeError: repeat count must be non-negative	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The String.prototype.repeat() method has been used. It has a count parameter indicating the number of times to repeat the string. It must be between 0 and less than positive Infinity and cannot be a negative number. The range of allowed values can be described like this: [0, +&#8734;).</p><pre><code>Invalid Cases:\nValid Cases:\n'abc'.repeat(0);    // ''\n'abc'.repeat(1);    // 'abc'\n'abc'.repeat(2);    // 'abcabc'\n'abc'.repeat(3.5);  // 'abcabcabc' (count will be converted to integer)\n\nValid Cases:\n'abc'.repeat(0);    // ''\n'abc'.repeat(1);    // 'abc'\n'abc'.repeat(2);    // 'abcabc'\n'abc'.repeat(3.5);  // 'abcabcabc' (count will be converted to integer)\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Negative_repetition_count

Warning: unreachable code after return statement	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Unreachable code after a return statement might occur in these situations:</p><pre><code>Invalid Cases:\nValid Cases:\nfunction f() {\n  var x = 3;\n  x += 4;\n  x -= 3;\n  return x;  // OK: return after all other statements\n}\n\nfunction f() {\n  return 3 + 4  // OK: semicolon-less return with expression on the same line\n}\n\nValid Cases:\nfunction f() {\n  var x = 3;\n  x += 4;\n  x -= 3;\n  return x;  // OK: return after all other statements\n}\n\nfunction f() {\n  return 3 + 4  // OK: semicolon-less return with expression on the same line\n}\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Stmt_after_return

InternalError: too much recursion	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A function that calls itself is called a recursive function. In some ways, recursion is analogous to a loop. Both execute the same code multiple times, and both require a condition (to avoid an infinite loop, or rather, infinite recursion in this case). When there is too much or infinite recursion, JavaScript will throw this error.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Too_much_recursion

ReferenceError: assignment to undeclared variable "x"	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A value has been assigned to an undeclared variable. In other words, there was an assignment without the var keyword. There are some differences between declared and undeclared variables, which might lead to unexpected results and that's why JavaScript presents an error in strict mode.</p><pre><code>Invalid Cases:\nValid Cases:\nfunction foo() {\n  "use strict";\n  var bar = true;\n}\nfoo();\nValid Cases:\nfunction foo() {\n  "use strict";\n  var bar = true;\n}\nfoo();</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Undeclared_var

ReferenceError: reference to undefined property "x"	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The script attempted to access an object property which doesn't exist. There are two ways to access properties; see the property accessors reference page to learn more about them.</p><pre><code>Invalid Cases:\nValid Cases:\n"use strict";\n\nvar foo = {};\n\n// Define the bar property\n\nfoo.bar = "moon";\nconsole.log(foo.bar); // "moon"\n\n// Test to be sure bar exists before accessing it\n\nif (foo.hasOwnProperty("bar") {\n  console.log(foo.bar);\n}\nValid Cases:\n"use strict";\n\nvar foo = {};\n\n// Define the bar property\n\nfoo.bar = "moon";\nconsole.log(foo.bar); // "moon"\n\n// Test to be sure bar exists before accessing it\n\nif (foo.hasOwnProperty("bar") {\n  console.log(foo.bar);\n}</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Undefined_prop

JavaScript makes no distinction between single-quoted strings and double-quoted strings. Escape sequences work in strings created with either single or double quotes. To fix this error, check if:</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Errors/Unterminated_string_literal

TypeError: variable "x" redeclares argument	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The same variable name occurs as a function parameter and is then redeclared using a var assignment in a function body again. typeerror variable x redeclares argument	R	TypeError: variable "x" redeclares argument										
Functions	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Generally speaking, a function is a "subprogram" that can be called by code external (or internal in the case of recursion) to the function. Like the program itself, a function is composed of a sequence of statements called the function body. Values can be passed to a function, and the function will return a value.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions
Arguments object	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The arguments object is an Array -like object corresponding to the arguments passed to a function.</p><p>The arguments object is a local variable available within all functions. You can refer to a function's arguments within the function by using the arguments object. This object contains an entry for each argument passed to the function, the first entry's index starting at 0. For example, if a function is passed three arguments, you can refer to them as follows:</p><pre><code>arguments[0]\narguments[1]\narguments[2]\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/arguments
arguments[@@iterator]()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The initial value of the @@iterator property is the same function object as the initial value of the Array.prototype.values property.</p><pre><code>arguments[Symbol.iterator]()</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/arguments/@@iterator
arguments.callee	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The arguments.callee property contains the currently executing function.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/arguments/callee
arguments.caller	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The obsolete arguments.caller property used to provide the function that invoked the currently executing function. This property has been removed and no longer works.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/arguments/caller
arguments.length	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The arguments.length property contains the number of arguments passed to the function.</p><pre><code>arguments.length</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/arguments/length
Arrow functions	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>An arrow function expression has a shorter syntax compared to function expressions and lexically binds the this value (does not bind its own this, arguments, super, or new.target). Arrow functions are always anonymous. These function expressions are best suited for non-method functions and they can not be used as constructors.</p><p>See also "ES6 In Depth: Arrow functions" on hacks.mozilla.org.</p><pre><code>var a = [\n  "Hydrogen",\n  "Helium",\n  "Lithium",\n  "Beryl&#173;lium"\n];\n\nvar a2 = a.map(function(s){ return s.length });\n\nvar a3 = a.map( s =&gt; s.length );</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/Arrow_functions
Default parameters	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Default function parameters allow formal parameters to be initialized with default values if no value or undefined is passed.</p><p>In JavaScript, parameters of functions default to undefined. However, in some situations it might be useful to set a different default value. This is where default parameters can help.</p><pre><code>function multiply(a, b) {\n  var b = (typeof b !== 'undefined') ?  b : 1;\n\n  return a*b;\n}\n\nmultiply(5); // 5\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/Default_parameters
getter	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The get syntax binds an object property to a function that will be called when that property is looked up.</p><p>Sometimes it is desirable to allow access to a property that returns a dynamically computed value, or you may want to reflect the status of an internal variable without requiring the use of explicit method calls. In JavaScript, this can be accomplished with the use of a getter. It is not possible to simultaneously have a getter bound to a property and have that property actually hold a value, although it is possible to use a getter and a setter in conjunction to create a type of pseudo-property.</p><pre><code>var log = ['test'];\nvar obj = {\n  get latest () {\n    if (log.length == 0) return undefined;\n    return log[log.length - 1]\n  }\n}\nconsole.log (obj.latest); // Will return "test".\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/get
Method definitions	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Starting with ECMAScript 2015 (ES6), a shorter syntax for method definitions on objects initializers is introduced. It is a shorthand for a function assigned to the method's name.</p><p>The shorthand syntax is similar to the getter and setter syntax introduced in ECMAScript 2015.</p><pre><code>var obj = {\n  foo: function() {},\n  bar: function() {}\n};</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/Method_definitions
Rest parameters	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The rest parameter syntax allows us to represent an indefinite number of arguments as an array.</p><p>If the last named argument of a function is prefixed with ..., it becomes an array whose elements from 0 (inclusive) to theArgs.length&#160;(exclusive) are supplied by the actual arguments passed to the function.</p><pre><code>// Before rest parameters, the following could be found:\nfunction f(a, b){\n  var args = Array.prototype.slice.call(arguments, f.length);\n\n  // &#8230;\n}\n\n// to be equivalent of\n\nfunction f(a, b, ...args) {\n  \n}\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/rest_parameters
setter	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The set syntax binds an object property to a function to be called when there is an attempt to set that property.</p><p>In JavaScript, a setter can be used to execute a function whenever a specified property is attempted to be changed. Setters are most often used in conjunction with getters to create a type of pseudo-property. It is not possible to simultaneously have a setter on a property that holds an actual value.</p><pre><code>var o = {\n  set current (str) {\n    this.log[this.log.length] = str;\n  },\n  log: []\n}\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/set
Array	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The JavaScript Array object is a global object that is used in the construction of arrays; which are high-level, list-like objects.</p><pre><code>[element0, element1, ..., elementN]\nnew Array(element0, element1[, ...[, elementN]])\nnew Array(arrayLength)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array
Array.prototype[@@iterator]()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The initial value of the @@iterator property is the same function object as the initial value of the values() property.</p><pre><code>arr[Symbol.iterator]()</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/@@iterator
get Array[@@species]	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Array[@@species] accessor property returns the Array constructor.</p><pre><code>Array[Symbol.species]\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/@@species
Array.prototype[@@unscopables]	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The @@unscopable symbol property contains property names that were not included in the ECMAScript standard prior to the ES2015 (ES6) version. These properties are excluded from with statement bindings.</p><pre><code>arr[Symbol.unscopables]</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/@@unscopables
Array.prototype.concat	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The concat() method returns a new array comprised of the array on which it is called joined with the array(s) and/or value(s) provided as arguments.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.concat ( [ item1 [ , item2 [ , … ] ] ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/concat
Array.prototype.copyWithin()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The copyWithin() method shallow copies part of an array to another location in the same array and returns it, without modifying its size.</p><pre><code>arr.copyWithin(target[, start[, end]])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/copyWithin
Array.prototype.entries()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The entries() method returns a new Array Iterator object that contains the key/value pairs for each index in the array.</p><pre><code>arr.entries()</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/entries
Array.prototype.every	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The every() method tests whether all elements in the array pass the test implemented by the provided function.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.every ( callbackfn [ , thisArg ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/every
Array.prototype.fill()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The fill() method fills all the elements of an array from a start index to an end index with a static value.</p><pre><code>arr.fill(value[, start = 0[, end = this.length]])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/fill
Array.prototype.filter	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The filter() method creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the provided function.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.filter ( callbackfn [ , thisArg ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/filter
Array.prototype.find()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The find() method returns a value in the array, if an element in the array satisfies the provided testing function. Otherwise undefined is returned.</p><pre><code>arr.find(callback[, thisArg])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/find
Array.prototype.findIndex()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The findIndex() method returns an index in the array, if an element in the array satisfies the provided testing function. Otherwise -1 is returned.</p><pre><code>arr.findIndex(callback[, thisArg])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/findIndex
Array.prototype.forEach	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The forEach() method executes a provided function once per array element.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.forEach ( callbackfn [ , thisArg ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach
Array.from()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Array.from() method creates a new Array instance from an array-like or iterable object.</p><pre><code>Array.from(arrayLike[, mapFn[, thisArg]])\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/from
Array.prototype.includes()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The includes() method determines whether an array includes a certain element, returning true or false as appropriate.</p><pre><code>var boolean = array.includes(searchElement[, fromIndex])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/includes
Array.prototype.indexOf	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The indexOf() method returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array, or -1 if it is not present.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.indexOf ( searchElement [ , fromIndex ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/indexOf
Array.isArray	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Array.isArray() determines whether the passed value is an Array.</p><pre><code>Array.isArray ( arg )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/isArray
Array.prototype.join	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The join() method joins all elements of an array into a string.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.join (separator)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join
Array.prototype.keys()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The keys() method returns a new Array Iterator that contains the keys for each index in the array.</p><pre><code>arr.keys()</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/keys
Array.prototype.lastIndexOf	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The lastIndexOf() method returns the last index at which a given element can be found in the array, or -1 if it is not present. The array is searched backwards, starting at fromIndex.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.lastIndexOf ( searchElement [ , fromIndex ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/lastIndexOf
array.length	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The length property represents an unsigned, 32-bit integer that is always numerically greater than the highest index in the array.</p><pre><code>arr.length</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/length
Array.prototype.map	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The map() method creates a new array with the results of calling a provided function on every element in this array.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.map ( callbackfn [ , thisArg ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map
Array.of()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Array.of() method creates a new Array instance with a variable number of arguments, regardless of number or type of the arguments.</p><pre><code>Array.of(element0[, element1[, ...[, elementN]]])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/of
Array.prototype.pop	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The pop() method removes the last element from an array and returns that element.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.pop ( )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/pop
Array.prototype	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Array.prototype property represents the prototype for the Array constructor.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/prototype
Array.prototype.push	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The push() method adds one or more elements to the end of an array and returns the new length of the array.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.push ( [ item1 [ , item2 [ , … ] ] ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/push
Array.prototype.reduce	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The reduce() method applies a function against an accumulator and each value of the array (from left-to-right) to reduce it to a single value.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.reduce ( callbackfn [ , initialValue ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/Reduce
Array.prototype.reduceRight	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The reduceRight() method applies a function against an accumulator and each value of the array (from right-to-left) has to reduce it to a single value.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.reduceRight ( callbackfn [ , initialValue ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/ReduceRight
Array.prototype.reverse	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The reverse() method reverses an array in place. The first array element becomes the last and the last becomes the first.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.reverse ( )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reverse
Array.prototype.shift	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The shift() method removes the first element from an array and returns that element. This method changes the length of the array.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.shift ( )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/shift
Array.prototype.slice	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The slice() method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array into a new array object.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.slice (start, end)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/slice
Array.prototype.some	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The some() method tests whether some element in the array passes the test implemented by the provided function.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.some ( callbackfn [ , thisArg ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/some
Array.prototype.sort	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The sort() method sorts the elements of an array in place and returns the array. The sort is not necessarily stable. The default sort order is according to string Unicode code points.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.sort (comparefn)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/sort
Array.prototype.splice	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The splice() method changes the content of an array by removing existing elements and/or adding new elements.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.splice (start, deleteCount [ , item1 [ , item2 [ , … ] ] ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/splice
Array.prototype.toLocaleString	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The toLocaleString() method returns a string representing the elements of the array. The elements are converted to Strings using their toLocaleString methods and these Strings are separated by a locale-specific String (such as a comma “,”).</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.toLocaleString ( )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/toLocaleString
Array.prototype.toSource()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The toSource() method returns a string representing the source code of the array.</p><pre><code>arr.toSource()</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/toSource
Array.prototype.toString	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The toString() method returns a string representing the specified array and its elements.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.toString ( )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/toString
Array.prototype.unshift	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The unshift() method adds one or more elements to the beginning of an array and returns the new length of the array.</p><pre><code>Array.prototype.unshift ( [ item1 [ , item2 [ , … ] ] ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/unshift
Array.prototype.values()	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The values() method returns a new Array Iterator object that contains the values for each index in the array.</p><pre><code>arr.values()</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/values
ArrayBuffer	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The ArrayBuffer object is used to represent a generic, fixed-length raw binary data buffer. You cannot directly manipulate the contents of an ArrayBuffer ; instead, you create one of the typed array objects or a DataView object which represents the buffer in a specific format, and use that to read and write the contents of the buffer.</p><pre><code>new ArrayBuffer(length)\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer
Atomics	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Atomics object provides atomic operations as static methods. They are used with SharedArrayBuffer objects.</p></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Atomics
SIMD.Bool16x8	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The SIMD.Bool16x8 data type is a 128-bit vector divided into 8 lanes storing boolean values.</p><pre><code>SIMD.Bool16x8(s0, s1, s2, s3, s4, s5, s6, s7);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Bool16x8
SIMD.Bool32x4	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The SIMD.Bool32x4 data type is a 128-bit vector divided into 4 lanes storing boolean values.</p><pre><code>SIMD.Bool32x4(x, y, z, w);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Bool32x4
SIMD.Bool64x2	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The SIMD.Bool64x2 data type is a 128-bit vector divided into 2 lanes storing boolean values.</p><pre><code>SIMD.Bool64x2(x, y);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Bool64x2
SIMD.Bool8x16	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The SIMD.Bool8x16 data type is a 128-bit vector divided into 16 lanes storing boolean values.</p><pre><code>SIMD.Bool8x16(s0,s1,s2,s3,s4,s5,s6,s7,s8,s9,s10,s11,s12,s13,s14,s15);</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Bool8x16

DataView	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The DataView view provides a low-level interface for reading and writing multiple number types in an ArrayBuffer irrespective of the platform's endianness.</p><pre><code>new DataView(buffer [, byteOffset [, byteLength]])</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/DataView
Date	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Creates a JavaScript Date instance that represents a single moment in time. Date objects are based on a time value that is the number of milliseconds since 1 January, 1970 UTC.</p><pre><code>new Date();\nnew Date(value);\nnew Date(dateString);\nnew Date(year, month[, day[, hour[, minutes[, seconds[, milliseconds]]]]]);\n</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date

Date.prototype.getYear	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The getYear() method returns the year in the specified date according to local time. Because getYear() does not return full years ("year 2000 problem"), it is no longer used and has been replaced by the getFullYear() method.</p><pre><code>Date.prototype.getYear ( )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/getYear
Date.now	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Date.now() method returns the number of milliseconds elapsed since 1 January 1970 00:00:00 UTC.</p><pre><code>Date.now ( )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/now
Date.parse	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The Date.parse() method parses a string representation of a date, and returns the number of milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 UTC or NaN if the string is unrecognised or, in some cases, contains illegal date values (e.g. 2015-02-31).</p><pre><code>Date.parse (string)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/parse

Date.prototype.setDate	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The setDate() method sets the day of the Date object relative to the beginning of the currently set month.</p><pre><code>Date.prototype.setDate (date)</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/setDate
Date.prototype.setFullYear	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The setFullYear() method sets the full year for a specified date according to local time. Returns new timestamp.</p><pre><code>Date.prototype.setFullYear (year [, month [, date ] ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/setFullYear
Date.prototype.setHours	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The setHours() method sets the hours for a specified date according to local time, and returns the number of milliseconds since 1 January 1970 00:00:00 UTC until the time represented by the updated Date instance.</p><pre><code>Date.prototype.setHours (hour [, min [, sec [, ms ] ] ] )</code></pre></section>	https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Date/setHours
